>From: "Chad Bohannan" <chad@...>
>
>hmm. you want the network to do a comparison between two images. That
>does sound hard.
>I was thinking you would use the two image comparison to create a
>fitness gradient yourself, then the networks would just output a single
>fitness value from a single input picture after they were trained on
>that input. It would essentially grade the picture from the data
>collected from you using the comparsion, not actually make a comparison
>itself. Doing a comparison with a network does at least double your
>search dimension...

True.  But it would be more accurate.  There isn't an absolute 'value' of an 
image.  Some are better because they make better use of color.  Others are 
better because of the visual balance.  Or the intense crispness of the 
focus.

In this case, A could be better than B, and B be better than C, but when 
compared, C is better than A.  For example, A has good image composition, B 
has good contrast, C has good color.  I might prefer A over B because when 
comparing them, the image composition makes it seem better.  B might have 
more drama in its contrast, and therefore be preferable over C.  But C's 
good composition isn't quite as good as A's, but it more than makes up for 
it in color saturation, so it wins over A.

So, comparing two photos to one another is the only way to really capture 
the essence of what I want to do.
